title: Nature's fortress: How cacti keep water in and predators out - Lucas C. Majure

options.label: C

title: Where will you be able to live in 20 years? - Carol Farbotko and Ingrid Boas

multiple-choice.question: What is a river delta, and how is it formed?

options.label: A
options.text: A river delta is a landmass formed when sediment carried by rivers is deposited where the river meets a larger body of water.

options.label: B
options.text: A river delta is a landmass formed when sediment carried by rivers is deposited at the river's source.

options.label: C
options.text: A river delta is a landmass formed when sediment carried by rivers is deposited in the middle of the river.

options.label: D
options.text: A river delta is a landmass formed when sediment carried by rivers is deposited at the river's mouth, but only during floods.

multiple-choice.question: What is happening to the coastline of Mohammadpur due to frequent flooding and erosion?

options.label: A
options.text: The coastline is expanding by 2.5 kilometers since 2000.

options.label: B
options.text: The coastline is remaining the same since 2000.

options.label: C
options.text: The coastline is being overtaken by the Meghna River by 2.5 kilometers since 2000.

options.label: D
options.text: The coastline is experiencing no changes since 2000.

multiple-choice.question: What is causing the rise in extreme weather events, according to scientists?

options.label: A
options.text: Earth's rapidly changing climate is causing the rise in extreme weather events.

options.label: B
options.text: Human activities such as deforestation and pollution are causing the rise in extreme weather events.

options.label: C
options.text: Natural disasters such as earthquakes and volcanic eruptions are causing the rise in extreme weather events.

options.label: D
options.text: The rise in extreme weather events is a natural phenomenon that occurs every few decades.

multiple-choice.question: What are some of the ways that residents of Mohammadpur are adapting to the changing climate?

options.label: A
options.text: They are moving to higher ground, building more resilient homes, and buying land on newly emerging islands.

options.label: B
options.text: They are abandoning their homes and livelihoods and moving to nearby cities.

options.label: C
options.text: They are doing nothing to adapt to the changing climate.

options.label: D
options.text: They are relying solely on government assistance to adapt to the changing climate.

multiple-choice.question: What are the governments and citizens of Kiribati and Tuvalu doing to address the challenges of climate change?

options.label: A
options.text: They are planting coastal mangrove forests, building up low-lying areas of land with dredged sand, and lobbying for countries with high emissions to reduce pollution.

options.label: B
options.text: They are abandoning their islands and moving to other countries.

options.label: C
options.text: They are relying solely on international aid to address the challenges of climate change.

options.label: D
options.text: They are doing nothing to address the challenges of climate change.

title: 2 questions to uncover your passion — and turn it into a career - Noeline Kirabo

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's dilemma six years ago?

options.label: A
options.text: They had a job that paid too little.

options.label: B
options.text: They had a comfortable job but felt unfulfilled.

options.label: C
options.text: They were struggling to find a job.

options.label: D
options.text: They were trying to decide on a career path.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's definition of passion?

options.label: A
options.text: A strong desire to make money.

options.label: B
options.text: A collection of life experiences that give one a deep sense of fulfillment.

options.label: C
options.text: A hobby that one enjoys in their free time.

options.label: D
options.text: A career that one is good at.

multiple-choice.question: What are the two reflective questions that the speaker's organization, Kyusa, asks to help individuals identify their passion?

options.label: A
options.text: What are your strengths and weaknesses? What are your long-term goals?

options.label: B
options.text: If you had all the time and money in the world, what would you do? What makes you happy or gives you a deep sense of fulfillment?

options.label: C
options.text: What are your values and interests? What kind of work environment do you prefer?

options.label: D
options.text: What are your skills and talents? What kind of lifestyle do you want to have?

multiple-choice.question: What is necessary for passion to become a career, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Passion alone is enough.

options.label: B
options.text: Passion must be coupled with the right set of skills, conditioning, and positioning.

options.label: C
options.text: Passion must be something that one is naturally talented at.

options.label: D
options.text: Passion must be something that one has experience in.

multiple-choice.question: What is the outcome for individuals who are able to turn their passion into a career, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: They become successful but may not be happy.

options.label: B
options.text: They become happy but may not be successful.

options.label: C
options.text: They become unstoppable and excel in their careers.

options.label: D
options.text: They become complacent and stagnant in their careers.

title: How the COVID-19 vaccines were created so quickly - Kaitlyn Sadtler and Elizabeth Wayne

multiple-choice.question: What is the key ingredient in mRNA vaccines that encodes the instructions for producing proteins?

options.label: A
options.text: DNA

options.label: B
options.text: mRNA (messenger ribonucleic acid)

options.label: C
options.text: Ribosome

options.label: D
options.text: Lipids

multiple-choice.question: How do mRNA vaccines introduce the body to a virus without causing an infection?

options.label: A
options.text: By injecting a weakened version of the live virus

options.label: B
options.text: By injecting a section of the virus

options.label: C
options.text: By encoding trillions of mRNA molecules with the instructions for a specific viral protein

options.label: D
options.text: By altering the body's DNA

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the lipid coating on the nanoparticles in mRNA vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: To protect the mRNA on its journey through the body and assist its entry into the cell

options.label: B
options.text: To activate the immune system

options.label: C
options.text: To alter the body's DNA

options.label: D
options.text: To cause an infection

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of the body producing antibodies to fight the viral protein introduced by the mRNA vaccine?

options.label: A
options.text: The recipient becomes sick with the virus

options.label: B
options.text: The recipient experiences brief fatigue, fever, and muscle soreness

options.label: C
options.text: The recipient's immune system is weakened

options.label: D
options.text: The recipient is protected against future infections of the virus

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential advantage of mRNA vaccines over traditional vaccines?

options.label: A
options.text: They contain weakened versions of live viruses

options.label: B
options.text: They require time-intensive research to prepare

options.label: C
options.text: They can be developed in weeks by swapping out a single component

options.label: D
options.text: They are more expensive to produce

options.label: B

title: A woman's fury holds lifetimes of wisdom - Tracee Ellis Ross

multiple-choice.question: What incident at the post office triggered the speaker's friend's fury?

options.label: A
options.text: Someone cut in front of her in line.

options.label: B
options.text: Someone physically moved her out of the way to get something.

options.label: C
options.text: Someone yelled at her for no reason.

options.label: D
options.text: Someone took her phone without asking.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the common thread between seemingly innocuous and horrific incidents of men helping themselves to women's bodies?

options.label: A
options.text: The intent behind the actions.

options.label: B
options.text: The level of physical harm caused.

options.label: C
options.text: The spectrum of behaviors that make space for more severe incidents.

options.label: D
options.text: The reaction of the women involved.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's point when she asks men to imagine someone taking their phone without asking?

options.label: A
options.text: To illustrate the importance of phone etiquette.

options.label: B
options.text: To demonstrate the absurdity of women's reactions to minor incidents.

options.label: C
options.text: To help men understand the feeling of being disrespected and having their boundaries crossed.

options.label: D
options.text: To show that men are more attached to their phones than women.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what has been the historical consequence for women who express anger or frustration?

options.label: A
options.text: They are praised for their strength and courage.

options.label: B
options.text: They are told to calm down and be more rational.

options.label: C
options.text: They are ignored and dismissed as overreacting.

options.label: D
options.text: They are rewarded with social and economic benefits.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's call to action for men in the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: To take charge and lead the movement towards women's equality.

options.label: B
options.text: To be accountable, self-reflective, compassionate, and open in their support for women.

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore the issue and let women handle it.

options.label: D
options.text: To become more aggressive in their pursuit of social change.

title: How do you know what's true? - Sheila Marie Orfano

multiple-choice.question: What is the Rashomon effect?

options.label: A
options.text: A phenomenon where individuals give identical accounts of the same event.

options.label: B
options.text: A phenomenon where individuals give significantly different but equally conceivable accounts of the same event.

options.label: C
options.text: A phenomenon where individuals give false accounts of the same event.

options.label: D
options.text: A phenomenon where individuals give no account of the same event.

multiple-choice.question: Under what conditions does the Rashomon effect usually occur?

options.label: A
options.text: When there is evidence to verify what really happened and no pressure to achieve closure.

options.label: B
options.text: When there is no evidence to verify what really happened and no pressure to achieve closure.

options.label: C
options.text: When there is no evidence to verify what really happened and pressure to achieve closure.

options.label: D
options.text: When there is evidence to verify what really happened and pressure to achieve closure.

multiple-choice.question: How do neuroscientists believe our memories are influenced?

options.label: A
options.text: By our previous experiences and internal biases.

options.label: B
options.text: By our previous experiences only.

options.label: C
options.text: By our internal biases only.

options.label: D
options.text: By neither our previous experiences nor internal biases.

multiple-choice.question: What happens when we recall a memory?

options.label: A
options.text: We remember the original experience accurately.

options.label: B
options.text: We remember the embellished memory instead of the original experience.

options.label: C
options.text: We forget the memory altogether.

options.label: D
options.text: We create a new memory.

multiple-choice.question: What question does the Rashomon effect raise about truth?

options.label: A
options.text: What is the objective truth?

options.label: B
options.text: Is there only one version of the truth?

options.label: C
options.text: Are there situations when an "objective truth" doesn't exist?

options.label: D
options.text: Can we ever know the truth?

title: Can you be awake and asleep at the same time? - Masako Tamaki

multiple-choice.question: What is asymmetrical sleep, and how does it differ from regular sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: Asymmetrical sleep is a state of deep sleep where both brain hemispheres are active.

options.label: B
options.text: Asymmetrical sleep is a state where one brain hemisphere is in deep sleep, and the other is in lighter sleep.

options.label: C
options.text: Asymmetrical sleep is a state where both brain hemispheres are in deep sleep, but the body is still awake.

options.label: D
options.text: Asymmetrical sleep is a state where the brain is completely awake, but the body is asleep.

multiple-choice.question: Why do dolphins sleep unihemispherically?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they need to conserve energy while swimming.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they need to stay alert for predators while sleeping.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they need to surface for air every few minutes to breathe.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they need to keep their newborn calves safe while sleeping.

multiple-choice.question: What is the "first night effect" in humans, and how is it related to asymmetrical sleep?

options.label: A
options.text: The "first night effect" is a phenomenon where humans sleep more soundly on their first night in a new place.

options.label: B
options.text: The "first night effect" is a phenomenon where humans sleep poorly on their first night in a new place due to asymmetrical sleep.

options.label: C
options.text: The "first night effect" is a phenomenon where humans experience deeper sleep in both hemispheres on their first night in a new place.

options.label: D
options.text: The "first night effect" is a phenomenon where humans experience lighter sleep in both hemispheres on their first night in a new place.

multiple-choice.question: How do frigatebirds sleep during their non-stop transoceanic flights?

options.label: A
options.text: They sleep with both hemispheres at a time for long periods.

options.label: B
options.text: They sleep with one hemisphere at a time for short periods.

options.label: C
options.text: They sleep with both hemispheres at a time for short periods.

options.label: D
options.text: They don't sleep at all during their flights.

multiple-choice.question: What is the benefit of unihemispheric sleep for dolphins?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows them to conserve energy while swimming.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows them to stay alert for predators while sleeping.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows them to get several hours of deep sleep in each hemisphere throughout a 24-hour period.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows them to sleep for longer periods without waking up.

options.text: Because liver is a natural remedy for menstrual cramps.

options.label: C

options.label: B
options.text: To release more blood and tissue.

options.label: C
options.text: To signal the start of a new menstrual cycle.

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: The suffering wrought by slavery and its lasting impact

options.label: C
options.text: The power of love to overcome adversity

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: As a liberating force that brings people together

options.label: C

options.text: As a historical event with no relevance to modern society

options.label: B
options.text: Linear storytelling

options.label: C
options.text: Blending perspectives and timelines

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

options.text: The importance of forgetting the past and moving on

options.label: B
options.text: The power of hate to destroy lives

options.label: C

options.label: D
